009package imagingbook.core.resource;
010
011import java.io.File;
012import java.io.IOException;
013import java.net.URI;
014import java.net.URISyntaxException;
015import java.net.URL;
016import java.nio.file.FileSystem;
017import java.nio.file.FileSystemNotFoundException;
018import java.nio.file.FileSystems;
019import java.nio.file.Files;
020import java.nio.file.Path;
021import java.nio.file.Paths;
022import java.util.ArrayList;
023import java.util.Collections;
024import java.util.Iterator;
025import java.util.List;
026import java.util.stream.Stream;
027
028
029/**
030 * <p>
031 * This class defines static methods for accessing resources. What makes things
032 * somewhat complex is the requirement that we want to retrieve resources
033 * located in the file system or contained inside a JAR file.
034 * </p>
035 * <p>
036 * Here is a typical URI for a JAR-embedded file:
037 * {@code "jar:file:/C:/PROJEC~2/parent/IM1D84~1/ImageJ/jars/jarWithResources.jar!/jarWithResouces/resources/clown.jpg"}
038 * </p>
039 *
040 * @author WB
041 * @version 2022/11/01
042 */
043public class ResourceUtils {
044        
045        /**
046         * Determines if the specified class was loaded from
047         * a JAR file or a .class file in the file system.
048         * 
049         * @param clazz the class
050         * @return true if contained in a JAR file, false otherwise
051         */
052        public static boolean isInsideJar(Class<?> clazz) {
053                URL url = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
054                String path = url.getPath();
055                File file = new File(path);
056                return file.isFile();
057        }
058        
059        /**
060         * Finds the URI for a resource relative to a specified class.
061         * The resource may be located in the file system or
062         * inside a JAR file.
063         * 
064         * @param clazz the anchor class
065         * @param relPath the resource path relative to the anchor class
066         * @return the URI or {@code null} if the resource was not found
067         */
068        public static URI getResourceUri(Class<?> clazz, String  relPath) {
069                URI uri = null;
070                if (isInsideJar(clazz)) {
071                        String classPath = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation().getFile();
072                        //String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', File.separatorChar);
073                        String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', '/');
074                        String compPath = "jar:file:" + classPath + "!/" + packagePath + "/" + relPath;
075                        try {
076                                uri = new URI(compPath);
077                        } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
078                                // throw new RuntimeException("getResourceURI: " + e.toString());
079                        }       
080                }
081                else {  // regular file path
082                        try {
083                                uri = clazz.getResource(relPath).toURI();
084                        } catch (Exception e) {
085                                //do nothing, just return null - was: throw new RuntimeException("getResourceURI: " + e.toString());
086                        }
087                }
088                return uri;
089        }
090        
091        /**
092         * <p>
093         * Finds the path to a resource relative to the location of some class.
094         * Example: Assume class C was loaded from file {@code someLocation/C.class}
095         * and there is a subfolder {@code someLocation/resources/} that contains 
096         * an image file {@code lenna.jpg}. Then the complete path to this image
097         * is obtained by 
098         * </p>
099         * <pre>
100         * Path path = getResourcePath(C.class, "resources/lenna.jpg");
101         * </pre>
102         * 
103         * @param clazz anchor class 
104         * @param relPath the path of the resource to be found (relative to the location of the anchor class)
105         * @return the path to the specified resource
106         * @version 2016/06/03: modified to return proper path to resource inside a JAR file.
107         */
108        public static Path getResourcePath(Class<?> clazz, String relPath) {
109                URI uri = getResourceUri(clazz, relPath);
110                if (uri != null) {
111                        return uriToPath(uri);
112                }
113                else {
114                        return null;
115                }
116        }
117        
118        /**
119         * Converts an {@link URI} to a {@link Path} for locations that are either in
120         * the file system or inside a JAR file.
121         * 
122         * @param uri the specified location
123         * @return the associated path
124         */
125        public static Path uriToPath(URI uri) {
126                Path path = null;
127                String scheme = uri.getScheme();
128                switch (scheme) {
129                case "jar":     {       // resource inside JAR file
130                        FileSystem fs = null;
131                        try { // check if this FileSystem already exists 
132                                fs = FileSystems.getFileSystem(uri);
133                        } catch (FileSystemNotFoundException e) {
134                                // that's OK to happen, the file system is not created automatically
135                        }
136                        
137                        if (fs == null) {       // must not create the file system twice
138                                try {
139                                        fs = FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, Collections.<String, Object>emptyMap());
140                                } catch (IOException e) {
141                                        throw new RuntimeException("uriToPath: " + e.toString());
142                                }
143                        }
144                        
145                        String ssp = uri.getSchemeSpecificPart();
146                        int startIdx = ssp.lastIndexOf('!');
147                        String inJarPath = ssp.substring(startIdx + 1);  // in-Jar path (after the last '!')
148                        path = fs.getPath(inJarPath);
149                        break;
150                }
151                case "file": {  // resource in ordinary file system
152                        path = Paths.get(uri);
153                        break;
154                }
155                default:
156                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot handle this URI type: " + scheme);
157                }
158                return path;
159        }
160        
161        public static Path[] getResourcePaths(URI uri) {
162                return getResourcePaths(uriToPath(uri));
163        }
164        
165        /**
166         * Method to obtain the paths to all files in a directory specified by a {@link Path}
167         * (non-recursively). This should work in an ordinary file system as well as a
168         * (possibly nested) JAR file.
169         * 
170         * @param path {@link Path} to a directory (may be contained in a JAR file)
171         * @return a possibly empty sequence of paths
172         */
173        public static Path[] getResourcePaths(Path path) {
174                // with help from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1429172/how-do-i-list-the-files-inside-a-jar-file, #10
175                if (!Files.isDirectory(path)) {
176                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("path is not a directory: " + path.toString());
177                }
178                
179                List<Path> pathList = new ArrayList<Path>();
180                Stream<Path> walk = null;
181                try {
182                        walk = Files.walk(path, 1);
183                } catch (IOException e) {
184                        e.printStackTrace();
185                }
186
187                for (Iterator<Path> it = walk.iterator(); it.hasNext();){
188                        Path p = it.next();
189                        if (Files.isRegularFile(p) && Files.isReadable(p)) {
190                                pathList.add(p);
191                        }
192                }
193                walk.close();
194                return pathList.toArray(new Path[0]);
195        }
196        
197        /**
198         * Use this method to obtain the paths to all files in a directory located
199         * relative to the specified class (non-recursively). This should work in an
200         * ordinary file system as well as a (possibly nested) JAR file.
201         * 
202         * @param clazz class whose source location defines the root
203         * @param relPath path relative to the root
204         * @return a possibly empty array of paths
205         */
206        public static Path[] getResourcePaths(Class<?> clazz, String relPath) {
207                return getResourcePaths(getResourceUri(clazz, relPath));
208        }
209        
210        /**
211         * Use this method to obtain the names of all files in a directory located
212         * relative to the specified class (non-recursively). This should work in an
213         * ordinary file system as well as a (possibly nested) JAR file.
214         * 
215         * @param clazz  class whose source location specifies the root
216         * @param relDir directory relative to the root
217         * @return a possibly empty array of file names
218         */
219        public static String[] getResourceFileNames(Class<?> clazz, String relDir) {
220                Path[] paths = ResourceUtils.getResourcePaths(clazz, relDir);
221                List<String> names = new ArrayList<>();
222                for (Path p : paths) {
223                        names.add(p.getFileName().toString());
224                }
225                return names.toArray(new String[0]);
226        }
227
228}
